source.title: Cable Yarding Using Intermediate Supports
source.notes: Observed Thunderbird TMY45 skyline with Maki Mini-Mak II carriage near Salmon Arm, BC (Bell Pole Company / Jay-Vee Yarding).

features: Designed for clamping and lateral yarding with skyline support jacks

site.location: Stukemapten Lake (north of Salmon Arm, BC)

crew.description: Yarder operator, chaser, full-time rigger, part-time rigger, two chokersetters (rigging crew often doubled when supports installed).
crew.notes: Part-time rigger brought to site for intermediate-support moves.

rigging_notes: Standing skyline (shotgun) with gravity outhaul; skyline rigged behind backspar.
Intermediate supports built from two 50–60 cm DBH second-growth stems ~6 m apart; rigging height 12–22 m.
Upper guylines crossed to provide lateral stability; skyline support cable tensioned with chain-saw winch forming an 'M' configuration.
Lateral yarding constrained to ~30 m each side of skyline to minimize hang-ups.
Guylines typically attached 0.5–1.5 m above tree-strap rigging point.
operation.notes: Skyline configured to harvest second-growth thinning corridors (clearcut history) where natural deflection was limited or convex.

intermediate_supports.snake_configuration: Skyline support cable ('snake') threaded through a tree block and tensioned back to a perpendicular tailhold, lifting the jack into an M-shaped support.
notes: Carriage passes intermediate supports by transferring load to the snake; skyline tension drops to empty-carriage levels while crossing.
Longer lateral reaches (>30 m) produced hang-ups that spiked skyline/guyline tensions.

cat_d8_backspar.source: FERIC FNCY12 Table 3 crew comparison (TMY45 vs Skylead) scaled by the 23% support-area share and TN-157 backspar duty fraction (≈58%).
cat_d8_backspar.ratio_method: Crew delta (5.5 vs 3.0 persons = 2.5 man-days) × support_area_fraction (0.23) × backspar_share (0.58) ⇒ 0.3335 yarder-SMH-equivalent of Cat D8 time per yarder SMH.
cat_d8_backspar.notes: Treats the Cat D8 operator as the primary intermediate-support machine whenever supports are active; CPI helper inflates the TR-45 D7G rate.

timberjack_450_trail_support.source: Same derivation as Cat D8: Table 3 crew delta scaled by support-area share with TN-157 non-backspar share (~42%) assigned to the Timberjack 450 helper.
timberjack_450_trail_support.ratio_method: Crew delta (2.5 man-days) × support_area_fraction (0.23) × trail_support_share (0.42) ⇒ 0.2415 yarder-SMH-equivalent of Timberjack time per yarder SMH.
timberjack_450_trail_support.notes: Represents the Timberjack 450 grapple skidder trail-support allowance for landing cleanup and strawline assists.

productivity.observation_period: July–October 1992 (67.5 productive shifts including early shutdowns)
observations: Learning curve in July reduced output; productivity stabilized at 166–189 m³/shift once intermediate-support rigging routines matured.
Man-day productivity ~32 m³ when including rigging crew; removing rigging-only personnel raises productivity to ~44 m³ per crew member.

tensions_and_clearance.reference: FERIC TN-258 backspar stress pilot study (Thunderbird TMY45 + Mini-Mak II).
skyline_tension_notes: Maximum skyline tension occurs when the turn is fully suspended; tension drops as carriage passes over intermediate supports because the snake bears the load.
Hang-ups during long lateral pulls significantly increase skyline tension; recommended to limit lateral distance and maintain clearance.
guyline_tension_notes: Critical guylines peaked during aborted loads (hang-ups or choked stumps). Crossed upper guylines helped limit lateral swing-induced loading.

guyline_kN.notes: Typical lateral distances; no major hang-ups.
24 kN spike caused by a hang-up on a longer lateral reach.
Higher suspended load kept tensions elevated until the carriage cleared the support.
Aborted load/choked stump drove the highest recorded guyline tension.

costing_status.notes: Owning/operating split reconstructed from LeDoux (1984) TMY-45 hourly costs (USD base) converted to CAD_1992 via StatCan CPI/FX and scaled to the FNCY12 5.5-person crew. Mini-Mak II + skyline support jacks treated as a CAD 33.5k attachment amortised over five years (1,200 SMH/year). Still lacks direct FERIC payroll/fuel logs—treat as interim BC rate until authentic 1992 bookkeeping surfaces.
